positions.position: The Pleasure Principle as Regulatory Mechanism
positions.content: The course of mental processes is automatically regulated by the pleasure-principle Any given mental process originates in unpleasant tension and determines a path leading to relaxation of tension (avoidance of pain/production of pleasure) This introduces the "economic" point of view into psychoanalysis The pleasure principle represents the most primitive regulatory function of the psychic apparatus
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: The Economic Point of View in Metapsychology
positions.content: A complete psychological theory must include topographical, dynamic, AND economic elements The economic element concerns the quantity and distribution of psychic energy/excitation This "metapsychological" approach is the most complete framework available Pain corresponds with increase in excitation quantity; pleasure with decrease
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Primacy of Quantity Over Quality in Affect
positions.content: The decisive factor for feeling is not absolute quantity but the amount of diminution or increase in a given time There is no simple direct proportion between stimulus strength and feeling intensity The primary processes generate more intense sensations than bound/secondary processes
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Fechner's Psycho-Physical Stability Principle
positions.content: Pleasure/pain bear psycho-physical relationship to conditions of stability and instability Pleasure is charged in proportion as psycho-physical movement approximates complete equilibrium beyond a certain limit Pain is charged in proportion as it departs from equilibrium beyond a certain limit Between limits exists an "area of aesthetic indifference"
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: The Constancy Principle
positions.content: The psychic apparatus attempts to keep quantity of excitation as low as possible or at least constant This tendency can be classified as Fechner's "tendency towards stability" Anything tending to increase excitation is felt as contrary to function (painful) The pleasure-principle is deduced from the principle of constancy
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Limitations on Pleasure Principle Supremacy
positions.content: It is not strictly correct to speak of supremacy of the pleasure-principle A strong tendency toward pleasure exists but is opposed by other forces and conditions Most psychic processes are NOT accompanied by pleasure (ordinary experience contradicts supremacy) The ultimate issue cannot always accord with the pleasure-tendency
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Reality-Principle as Modification
positions.content: The pleasure-principle is adjusted to primary mode of operation For organism preservation in external world, it is ab initio useless and dangerous Under ego's self-preservation instinct, it is replaced by reality-principle Reality-principle demands postponement of satisfaction, renunciation of possibilities, temporary endurance of pain Pleasure-principle remains method of sex-impulses longer (less educable)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Repression as Source of Pain
positions.content: Another source of pain: conflicts during ego development toward higher organization Instincts or portions prove irreconcilable and are split off by repression If repressed impulses achieve circuitous gratification, success is experienced as pain by ego All neurotic pain is "pleasure which cannot be experienced as such"
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Two Primary Sources of Pain
positions.content: Perceptual pain: perception of urge of unsatisfied instincts OR external painful/dangerous stimuli The psychic apparatus can be guided by pleasure-principle or reality-principle in response Most pain experiences don't impugn pleasure-principle supremacy
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Traumatic Neurosis and Mechanical Shock
positions.content: Traumatic neurosis arises after severe mechanical shock where life danger is involved War proved these are not merely organic nerve injury from mechanical force Clinical picture approaches hysteria in motor symptoms but shows stronger subjective suffering Shows comprehensive general weakening/shattering of mental functions
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Fright vs. Fear vs. Apprehension
positions.content: Three terms incorrectly used synonymously but admit clear distinction in relation to danger Apprehension (Angst): expectation of danger and preparation, even if unknown Fear (Furcht): requires definite object of which one is afraid Fright (Schreck): condition when encountering danger without preparation; emphasizes surprise element
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Apprehension as Protection Against Trauma
positions.content: Apprehension cannot produce traumatic neurosis Apprehension contains something protecting against fright and fright-neurosis The element of surprise/lack of preparation is crucial causal factor Concurrent physical injury tends to PREVENT neurosis (paradoxically)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Dreams in Traumatic Neurosis Violate Pleasure Principle
positions.content: In traumatic neuroses, dream life continually returns patient to disaster situation with renewed terror This contradicts understanding of dreams as wish-fulfillment Either dream function suffers dislocation in this condition, OR we must consider masochistic ego tendencies These dreams attempt to restore control by developing apprehension retroactively
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Children's Play as Mastery Mechanism
positions.content: Child's play of fort-da (gone-there) game demonstrates repetition of unpleasant experiences The 18-month-old repeated mother's departure as game despite its unpleasantness Child was passive in experience but active in play repetition This may serve impulse to obtain mastery independent of pleasure/pain
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Play Transforms Passivity to Activity
positions.content: In play, child applies to playfellow the unpleasant occurrence that befell himself Child avenges himself on person of proxy This transformation from passivity of experience to activity of play is key mechanism Even painful experiences become subjects of play (doctor examining throat)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Repetition-Compulsion in Psychoanalytic Treatment
positions.content: Patient cannot recall all repressed material Patient is obliged to REPEAT as current experience instead of recollecting as past fragment Reproduction appears with unwelcome fidelity, always contains fragment of infantile sex-life/Oedipus complex Played regularly in sphere of transference (relationship to physician)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Earlier Neurosis Replaced by Transference-Neurosis
positions.content: When treatment reaches certain point, earlier neurosis is replaced by fresh transference-neurosis Physician limits scope of transference-neurosis, forcing as much as possible into memory Different relation between memory and reproduction established for each case Success requires some measure of ascendency remains to recognize apparent reality as reflection of forgotten past
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Repetition-Compulsion Proceeds from the Repressed
positions.content: The unconscious (repressed material) offers no resistance to cure Resistance proceeds from same higher ego levels that originally caused repression Repetition-compulsion must be ascribed to repressed element in unconscious Could not express itself till treatment loosened repression
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Repetition-Compulsion Beyond Pleasure Principle
positions.content: Repetition-compulsion revives past experiences containing no pleasure potentiality These could at no time have been satisfactions, even of repressed impulses Most of what is revived by repetition-compulsion brings discomfort to ego This promotes repressed impulses activities but is pain for one system, satisfaction for another
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Normal Life Exhibits Repetition-Compulsion
positions.content: Normal persons show repetition-compulsion in life history Gives impression of pursuing fate or daemonic trait in destiny Life history appears self-imposed and determined by infantile influences Examples: benefactors always betrayed, friendships always ending in treachery, lovers following same relationship pattern
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Active vs. Passive Repetition
positions.content: Less astonishing when person's active behavior produces repetition (unalterable character trait) More striking when person seems passive, experiencing same fate repeatedly without influence Example: woman who married three men who each fell ill and she nursed till death Tasso's Tancred unwittingly killing beloved Clorinda twice
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Reality of Repetition-Compulsion Established
positions.content: Safe to assume real existence of repetition-compulsion in psychic life going beyond pleasure-principle Relates to dreams of shock-patients and children's play-impulse Only in rare cases can workings be recognized in pure form without cooperation of other motives
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Consciousness Not Universal Characteristic
positions.content: Consciousness cannot be most general characteristic of psychic processes but merely special function Consciousness yields perceptions from without and feelings of pleasure/pain from within System W-Bw (perceptual consciousness) positioned on boundary between outer and inner Agrees with localizing tendencies placing consciousness in cortical layer
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Memory Traces vs. Consciousness Incompatible
positions.content: Becoming conscious and leaving memory-trace are processes incompatible in same system In system Bw, excitation becomes conscious but leaves no lasting trace All memory traces relied upon come from propagation to next systems inward Consciousness arises in place of memory-trace
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: System Bw Characteristics from Exposed Position
positions.content: System Bw characterized by excitation not leaving permanent alteration but discharging in becoming conscious This departure from general rule requires explanation Factor accounting for this is system's exposed situation—immediate contact with outer world Analogous to living organism's surface differentiation
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: The Living Vesicle and Protective Barrier
positions.content: Living substance as undifferentiated vesicle has surface exposed and differentiated by position Constant external stimuli impact causes lasting alteration to certain depth Forms "rind" burned through by stimulation effects, presenting favorable conditions for reception Cannot undergo further modification; elements no longer susceptible to lasting alteration but capable of giving rise to consciousness
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Protection Against Stimuli More Important Than Reception
positions.content: For living organism, protection against stimuli almost more important than reception Protective barrier equipped with own energy store Must protect special forms of energy-transformation within from equalizing/destructive influence of enormous external energies Reception serves to collect information about direction/nature of external stimuli in small samples
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Time as Mode of System W-Bw Functioning
positions.content: Unconscious mental processes are "timeless" Not arranged chronologically; time alters nothing in them; idea of time cannot be applied Abstract conception of time derived from mode of functioning of system W-Bw Corresponds with self-perception of that system
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Inner Excitations Bypass Protective Barrier
positions.content: Toward outer world exists barrier against stimuli reducing excitation effect Toward inner, no protection possible; excitations pursue direct path in undiminished mass Certain characteristics produce series of pleasure-pain feelings Inner excitations more proportionate to system's operation than outer stimuli streaming in
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Origin of Projection
positions.content: Two things determined by these conditions: preponderance of pleasure/pain feelings over external stimuli Tendency to treat inner excitations bringing overplus of pain as if acting from without This allows applying defensive barrier measures against them This is origin of projection with important role in pathological states
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Trauma Breaks Through Protective Barrier
positions.content: External excitations strong enough to break through barrier against stimuli are "traumatic" Concept of trauma involves relationship to otherwise efficacious barrier External trauma provokes extensive disturbance in organism's energy working Sets in motion every protective measure; pleasure-principle put out of action
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Binding Traumatic Stimuli
positions.content: Flooding psychic apparatus with large stimulus masses cannot be prevented after barrier breach Another task presents itself: bring stimulus under control, "bind" stimulus mass in psyche This enables discharge Specific discomfort of bodily pain results from local breaking through of protective barrier
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Counter-Charge Mechanism
positions.content: From all sides "charging energy" called on to create correspondingly high "charges" around breach Immense "counter-charge" set up, impoverishing other psychic systems Wide-spread paralysis/diminution of other psychic activity follows This demonstrates even highly charged system can receive new energy streaming in
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Binding Force Proportionate to Quiescent Charge
positions.content: The more intense intrinsic quiescent charge, the greater binding force The lower system's charge, the less capable of receiving streaming energy Therefore more violent consequences when barrier broken through Not valid objection that intensifying charges is merely direct action of excitation mass
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Free-Flowing vs. Quiescent Energy Distinction
positions.content: Must distinguish two ways system may be filled with energy (Breuer's proposition) Difference between "charging" that is free-flowing/striving for discharge vs. quiescent May admit conjecture that binding energy streaming into psychic apparatus consists in translating from free-flowing to quiescent state This distinction fundamental to metapsychology
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Traumatic Neurosis as Barrier Rupture
positions.content: May regard ordinary traumatic neurosis as result of extensive rupture of barrier against stimuli Old naïve "shock" doctrine comes into its own, apparently opposing later psychological view Psychoanalytic conception far from identical with crudest shock theory Seeks to understand effect through breaking barrier and consequent tasks
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Fright as Failure of Preparation
positions.content: Fright retains meaning as failure of apprehension mechanism to make proper preparation Including over-charging of systems first receiving stimulus Due to lower charging degree, systems hardly able to bind oncoming excitation masses Apprehensive preparation with over-charging represents last line of defense against stimuli
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Dreams Re-establish Preparation Retroactively
positions.content: Dreams of traumatic neurosis patients regularly returning to disaster don't serve wish-fulfillment Serve another purpose that must be fulfilled before pleasure-principle can begin sway Attempts at restoring control by developing apprehension (pretermission caused neurosis) Affords insight into function independent of pleasure-principle, of earlier origin than attaining pleasure
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: First Exception to Dream Wish-Fulfillment
positions.content: Moment to concede first exception to principle that dream is wish-fulfillment Anxiety dreams are no exception (repeatedly shown) Punishment dreams are wish-fulfillment of guilt sense But traumatic neurosis dreams and childhood trauma recall dreams in analysis don't permit wish-fulfillment classification
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Dreams May Have Prehistoric Past Function
positions.content: Function of dream to remove motives interrupting sleep by wish-fulfillments not its original function Could secure this control only after whole psychic life accepted pleasure-principle domination If there is "beyond the pleasure-principle," logical to admit prehistoric past for wish-fulfilling dream tendency No contradiction of later function when this tendency broken through
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Instinct as Conservative Tendency
positions.content: An instinct is tendency innate in living organic matter impelling toward reinstatement of earlier condition One which it had to abandon under external disturbing forces A kind of organic elasticity or manifestation of inertia in organic life This conception seems strange since we usually see instinct as urging toward change/development
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Evidence from Animal Behavior
positions.content: Fish undertaking arduous journeys at spawning to reach earlier homes of their kind Migratory flights of birds of passage seeking earlier habitats These appear to confirm instinct as historically conditioned Heredity and embryology provide imposing proofs of organic compulsion to repetition
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Embryonic Development as Repetition
positions.content: Germ cell obliged to repeat in development structures of all ancestral forms Though in fleeting/curtailed fashion instead of hastening to final shape Mechanical explanation impossible except in trifling particulars Historical explanation cannot be disregarded
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Regeneration as Conservative Instinct
positions.content: Power of reproduction extends far up animal kingdom Lost organ replaced by growth of new one exactly like it Demonstrates conservative tendency in organic matter
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: All Instincts Aim at Earlier Condition
positions.content: If all instincts have as aim reinstatement of earlier condition All results of organic development must be credited to external disturbing/distracting influences Rudimentary creature would not have wanted to change from beginning Would merely repeat same existence course if circumstances remained same
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Evolution Result of External Forces
positions.content: Evolution of earth and relation to sun left imprint on organism development Conservative organic instincts absorbed all enforced alterations in life course Stored them for repetition Present delusive appearance of forces striving for change/progress while merely seeking old goal by old and new ways
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: The Goal of Life is Death
positions.content: Final goal of all organic striving can be stated Would be counter to conservative instinct nature if goal were state never hitherto reached Must be ancient starting point which living being left long ago If we assume everything living dies from internal causes and returns to inorganic "The goal of all life is death" and "The inanimate was there before the animate"
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Origin of Life as Awakening of Properties
positions.content: At some time, by operation of force still completely baffling Properties of life awakened in lifeless matter Perhaps process resembled later arising of consciousness in living matter stratum Tension aroused in previously inanimate matter strove to attain equilibrium
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: First Instinct Was to Return to Lifelessness
positions.content: The first instinct present was to return to lifelessness Living substance at that time had death within easy reach Probably only short life course to run, determined by chemical structure Through long period, living substance constantly created anew and easily extinguished
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Circuitous Routes to Death
positions.content: Decisive external influences altered surviving substance Compelled ever greater deviations from original life path Ever more complicated/circuitous routes to attainment of death goal These circuitous ways to death, retained by conservative instincts, are phenomena of life as we know it
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Self-Preservation Instincts as Paths to Death
positions.content: If exclusively conservative nature of instincts accepted as true Self-preservative instincts stand in remarkable contrast to supposition that whole life serves bringing death Theoretic significance of self-preservation/power/self-assertion instincts shrinks to nothing They are part-instincts designed to secure peculiar path to death and ward off other possibilities
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Organism Resolved to Die Only Its Own Way
positions.content: Organism resolved to die only in its own way Even these watchmen of life were originally myrmidons of death Paradox: living organism resists with all energy influences (dangers) that could help reach life-goal by short way This just the behavior characterizing pure instinct as contrasted with intelligent striving
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sexual Instincts as Exception
positions.content: Sexual instincts lead to quite another point of view Not all organisms yielded to external compulsion driving toward ever further development Many maintained themselves on low level up to present time Not all elementary organisms making up higher life form take part in whole path to natural end (death)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Reproductive Cells Retain Original Structure
positions.content: Reproductive cells probably retain original structure of living substance After given time, detach from parent organism Charged with all inherited and newly acquired instinctive dispositions Under favorable conditions begin to develop—repeat cycle to which they owe origin
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Germ Cells Operate Against Death
positions.content: One portion of substance carries development to finish Another portion as new germinal core harks back to beginning of development Reproductive cells operate against death of living substance Able to win what seems potential immortality (perhaps only lengthening path to death)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Fortification Through Mingling
positions.content: Of highest significance: reproductive cell fortified for function or becomes capable only by mingling with another like yet different Germ cells care for destinies of elementary organisms surviving individual Concern themselves with safe sheltering while defenseless Finally bring about conjunction with other reproductive cells
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sexual Instincts as Specially Conservative
positions.content: Sexual instincts conservative in same sense as others (reproduce earlier conditions) Conservative in higher degree: specially resistant to external influences More conservative in wider sense: preserve life itself for longer time They are actual life-instincts
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Contradiction Between Life and Death Instincts
positions.content: Fact that sexual instincts run counter to trend of other instincts leading toward death indicates contradiction This contradiction recognized by theory of neuroses as full of significance Oscillating rhythm in life of organisms: one group presses forward to final goal quickly Other flies back at certain point to traverse same stretch again, prolonging journey duration
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sexuality Not Present at Dawn of Life
positions.content: Although sexuality and sex distinction certainly didn't exist at dawn of life Remains possible that instincts later described as sexual were active from very beginning Took up part of opposition to role of ego-instincts then, not only at later time
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: No General Impulse Toward Higher Development
positions.content: Apart from sexual instincts, are there really no other instincts than those with object of reinstating earlier condition? Not aware of satisfactory example in organic world running counter to suggested characteristic Existence of general impulse toward higher development cannot be established Though some such development line is unquestionable as fact
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Higher Development Often Balanced by Retrogression
positions.content: Often merely question of our own valuation when we pronounce one stage higher than another Biology makes clear higher development in one particular often purchased/balanced by retrogression in another Plenty of animal forms whose youthful stages teach their development took retrograde character Higher development and retrogression alike might be results of external forces impelling toward adaptation
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: No Impulse Toward Perfection in Man
positions.content: Many find it hard to abandon belief that in man dwells impulse toward perfection Which brought him to present intellectual/ethical heights From which development into superman might be expected But I do not believe in existence of such inner impulse
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Striving for Perfection as Repression Effect
positions.content: Development of man doesn't seem to need explanation differing from animal development Restless striving toward further perfection observable in minority easily explicable as result of instinct repression What is most valuable in human culture built on repression of instinct Repressed instinct never ceases striving after complete satisfaction
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Excess Demand Creates Driving Momentum
positions.content: Complete satisfaction would consist in repetition of primary experience of satisfaction All substitution/reaction-formations and sublimations avail nothing toward relaxing continual tension Out of excess of satisfaction demanded over that found is born driving momentum Allows no abiding in any situation presented, "urges ever forward, ever unsubdued" (Mephisto)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Path Back to Satisfaction Generally Barred
positions.content: Path in other direction, back to complete satisfaction, usually barred by resistances maintaining repressions Nothing remains but to proceed in other still unobstructed direction of development Without prospect of bringing process to conclusion or attaining goal What occurs in neurotic phobia development (attempt at flight from instinct satisfaction) gives prototype
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Impulse Toward Perfection Not Universal
positions.content: Cannot possibly ascribe ostensible impulse toward perfection to all human beings Dynamic conditions quite generally present But economic relations seem only in rare cases to favor phenomenon This is why we cannot ascribe it universally
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sharp Antithesis: Ego-Instincts vs. Sexual Instincts
positions.content: Discussion results in sharp antithesis between ego-instincts and sexual instincts Former impelling toward death, latter toward life preservation Result we ourselves must find far from adequate in many respects Only for former can we claim conservative/regressive character corresponding to repetition-compulsion
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Ego-Instincts Spring from Vitalizing Inanimate Matter
positions.content: According to hypothesis, ego-instincts spring from vitalizing of inanimate matter Have as their aim reinstatement of lifelessness As to sexual instincts: obvious they reproduce primitive states of living being
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sexual Union as Condition for Immortality
positions.content: Aim sexual instincts strive for by every means is union of two specifically differentiated germ cells If this union doesn't take place, germ cell dies like all other elements of multicellular organism Only on this condition can sexual function prolong life and lend semblance of immortality
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Question of What Sexual Reproduction Repeats
positions.content: Of what important happening in living substance development is sexual reproduction/copulation the repetition? Do not know how to answer this question Would feel relieved if whole argument structure proved erroneous Opposition of ego-(death-)instincts and sexual (life-)instincts would then disappear
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Testing Natural Death Assumption
positions.content: Turn back to assumption that all life must die from internal causes Made this assumption light-heartedly because it doesn't seem to be one Accustomed to think so; every poet encourages idea Perhaps resolved to think so because there lies certain consolation in belief
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Natural Death May Be Illusion
positions.content: Perhaps belief in death as necessary consequence of inner law is illusion fashioned to endure burden of existence Certainly not primordial belief Idea of "natural death" alien to primitive races; they ascribe every death to enemy or evil spirit influence So let us turn to biological science to test belief
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Little Agreement Among Biologists on Death
positions.content: May be astonished to find how little agreement exists among biologists on natural death question Very conception of death altogether eludes them Certain average life length among higher animals argues for death from inner causes But circumstance that certain large animals/giant trees reach very great age removes this impression
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Weismann's Mortal Soma vs. Immortal Germ-Plasm
positions.content: Weismann originated distinction of living substance into mortal and immortal half Mortal is body in narrower sense (soma), alone subject to natural death Germ cells potentially immortal insofar as capable of developing into new individual under favorable conditions Can surround themselves with new soma
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Weismann's Differentiation Only for Multicellular Organisms
positions.content: Weismann admits differentiation between mortal soma and immortal germ-plasm only for multicellular organisms With unicellular beings, individual and reproductive cell still one and same Unicellular he affirms to be potentially immortal Death appears only among metazoa (multicellular)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Death as Purposive Contrivance for Multicellular
positions.content: This death of higher organisms is natural death from inner causes But doesn't depend on inherent quality of living substance Not to be conceived as absolute necessity based on nature of life Rather purposive contrivance, phenomenon of adaptation to external life conditions
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Death Became Possible and Expedient
positions.content: After differentiation of corporeal cells into soma and germ-plasm Indefinite prolongation of individual life would have become quite inexpedient luxury With appearance of this differentiation, death became possible and expedient Since then soma dies after certain time from internal causes
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Propagation Not Introduced With Death
positions.content: Propagation not first introduced with death On contrary, is primordial property of living matter like growth, from which it originated Life has gone on uninterruptedly from inception on earth
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Late Death Doesn't Help Death Instinct Theory
positions.content: To concede natural death to higher organisms doesn't greatly help our case If death is late acquisition of life, then death instincts traceable to beginning no longer come into question Multicellular organisms may continue to die from internal causes (defect of differentiation or metabolism imperfections) Such conception/derivation more nearly approaches ordinary human view than unwonted assumption of death-instincts
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Debate Over Weismann Not Decisive
positions.content: Discussion centered round Weismann's assertions has had no decisive result in any direction Many writers reverted to Goette's standpoint (1883) seeing in death direct consequence of propagation Hartmann doesn't regard appearance of corpse as death characteristic Defines it as "definitive end of individual development"
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Protozoa Also Subject to Death
positions.content: In Hartmann's sense, protozoa also subject to death With them death invariably coincides with propagation But is so to speak disguised by latter Whole substance of parent organism may be absorbed directly into new individuals
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Woodruff's Immortality Experiment
positions.content: American Woodruff instituted culture of ciliated infusorium (slipper-animalcule) Reproduces by division into two individuals Traced propagation to 3029th generation when discontinued experiment Last descendant just as lively as original ancestor without sign of age/degeneration If such numbers convincing, immortality of protozoa seemed experimentally demonstrable
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Contradictory Findings on Protozoa Aging
positions.content: Other investigators (Maupas, Calkins) found contradicting Woodruff Even these infusoria after certain divisions become weaker, decrease in size Lose portion of organization, finally die without invigorating influences According to this, protozoa die after senile decay phase like higher animals In direct contravention of Weismann's view
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Conjugation Prevents Aging
positions.content: First fact affording firm foothold: if animalculae have opportunity to mingle (conjugate) when showing no age signs Afterwards again separating, they remain exempt from age, are "rejuvenated" Conjugation doubtless prototype of sexual propagation of higher organisms As yet nothing to do with multiplication; confined to mingling of both individuals' substances
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Invigorating Influence Can Be Replaced
positions.content: Invigorating influence of conjugation can be replaced by certain stimulation modes Changes in nutrient fluid composition, raising temperature, or shaking J. Loeb's famous experiment: applying chemical stimuli to sea-urchin ova Brought about division processes usually taking place only after fertilization
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Infusoria Die From Own Metabolic Products
positions.content: Probable that infusoria brought to natural death through own vital process Contradiction between Woodruff and others arises from Woodruff placing each generation in fresh nutrient When he refrained, observed same aging signs as other investigators Concluded animalculae injured by metabolism products given off into surrounding fluid
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Own Metabolic Products Fatal
positions.content: Able to prove convincingly only products of its OWN metabolism had death-bringing effect For in solution over-saturated with distantly related species waste products Very same animalculae throve excellently which in own nutrient inevitably perished Thus left to itself, infusorium dies natural death from imperfect disposal of own metabolic products
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: All Higher Animals Die From Same Inability
positions.content: Perhaps all higher animals die ultimately from same inability To dispose of their own metabolic products This suggests universal mechanism of natural death
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Doubt About Studying Death in Protozoa
positions.content: Doubt may occur whether good purpose served looking for natural death answer in protozoa study Primitive organization of these life forms may conceal important conditions Present in them too but recognizable only among higher animals where they achieved morphological expression
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Dynamic vs. Morphological Point of View
positions.content: If we abandon morphological point of view for dynamic May be matter of entire indifference whether natural death of protozoa can be proved With them substance later recognized as immortal not yet separated from part subject to death
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Death-Instincts May Be Active from Beginning
positions.content: Instinctive forces endeavoring to conduct life to death might be active in protozoa from beginning Yet their effect might be so obscured by life-preserving forces That direct evidence of existence becomes hard to establish Biologist observations allow us to assume such death-ward tending inner processes even among protozoa
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Even Protozoa Immortality Doesn't Invalidate Hypothesis
positions.content: Even if protozoa prove immortal in Weismann's sense His assertion that death is late acquisition holds good only of outward death manifestations Doesn't invalidate hypothesis of processes impelling toward death Our expectation that biology would entirely discount death-instincts recognition not fulfilled
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Weismann Distinction Resemblance Remains Unshaken
positions.content: Striking resemblance between Weismann's separation of soma/germ-plasm and our distinction between death/life-instincts remains unshaken Retains its value despite other considerations Fundamental analogy persists
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Hering's Anabolic vs. Katabolic Processes
positions.content: According to E. Hering's theory of processes in living matter Course through it uninterruptedly two kinds of processes of opposite direction One anabolic/assimilatory, other katabolic/disintegrating Shall we venture to recognize in these two directions activity of our two instinctive tendencies?
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Convergence with Schopenhauer
positions.content: Cannot disguise that we steered unawares into haven of Schopenhauer's philosophy For whom death is "real result" of life and therefore in so far its aim While sexual instinct is incarnation of will to live This convergence noteworthy
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Multicellularity as Life-Prolongation Means
positions.content: According to general opinion, union of numerous cells into one vital connection (multicellularity of organisms) Has become means to prolongation of their life span One cell helps preserve life of others Cell-community can go on living even if single cells perish
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Conjugation Has Preservative/Rejuvenating Effect
positions.content: Also conjugation (temporary mingling of two unicellular entities) Has preservative and rejuvenating effect on both Attempt might be made to transfer Libido theory from psychoanalysis to cell relationships
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Libido Theory Applied to Cells
positions.content: Might imagine vital/sexual instincts active in every cell Take other cells for their "object" Partially neutralize their death-instincts (processes stimulated by these) So preserve those cells in life While other cells do same for them, and still others sacrifice themselves in exercise of libidinous function
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Germ Cells Behave Narcissistically
positions.content: Germ cells themselves would behave in completely "narcissistic" fashion As accustomed to describe in neuroses theory when individual concentrates libido on ego Gives out none for charging objects Need their libido—activity of vital instincts—for themselves as provision for later enormous constructive activity
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Malignant Growths as Narcissistic
positions.content: Perhaps cells of malignant growths destroying organism can also be considered narcissistic in same sense Pathology prepared to regard kernels of them as congenital in origin Ascribe embryonal attributes to them Thus Libido of sexual instincts would coincide with Eros of poets/philosophers holding together all things living
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Initial Opposition: Sexual vs. Ego-Instincts
positions.content: Analysis of transference-neuroses forced notice first of opposition between sexual instincts directed toward object And other instincts only imperfectly discerned, provisionally described as ego-instincts Among latter, those subserving individual self-preservation had first claim for recognition
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Psychoanalysis Adhered to "Hunger and Love"
positions.content: Psychoanalysis could not dispense with some hypothesis as to instincts Adhered to begin with to popular distinction typically represented by phrase "hunger and love" At least no new arbitrary creation With this adequately covered considerable distance in psychoneuroses analysis
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Extension of Sexuality Concept
positions.content: Conception of "sexuality"—and therewith of sexual instinct—certainly had to be extended Till it included much not coming into category of propagation function This led to outcry enough in severe/superior or merely hypocritical world
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Psychoanalysis Approached Psychological Ego
positions.content: Next step followed when Psychoanalysis able to feel way nearer to psychological ego At first known only as repressing, censoring agency Capable of constituting defenses and reaction-formations
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Objections to Narrow Libido Concept
positions.content: Critical and far-seeing minds long raised objections to narrowing libido concept to sexual instinct energy directed to object But they omitted to say whence they obtained fuller comprehension Failed to deduce anything from it of value for Psychoanalysis
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Libido Withdrawn from Object to Ego
positions.content: In course of more deliberate advance came under observation how regularly libido withdrawn from object and directed toward ego (introversion) Through study of child's libido-development in earliest phases became clear Ego is true and original reservoir of libido, extended to object only from this
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Ego as Sexual Object
positions.content: Ego took its place as one of sexual objects Was immediately recognized as choicest among them Where libido thus remained attached to ego it was termed "narcissistic"
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Narcissistic Libido as Sexual Instinct Energy
positions.content: This narcissistic libido naturally also expression of sexual instincts energy in analytical sense Which now had to be identified with "instincts of self-preservation" admitted from first Whereupon original antithesis between ego-instincts and sexual instincts became inadequate
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Part of Ego-Instincts Recognized as Libidinous
positions.content: Part of ego-instincts recognized as libidinous In ego sexual instincts found to be active—probably in addition to others Nevertheless justified in saying old formula still valid: psychoneurosis arises from conflict between ego-instincts and sexual instincts
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Difference Now Topographical, Not Qualitative
positions.content: Difference of two kinds of instincts supposed originally qualitative Has now to be defined otherwise, namely on topographical basis Particularly transference-neurosis still seen as result of conflict between ego and libidinous investment of object
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Accentuating Libidinous Character of Self-Preservation
positions.content: More compelled now to accentuate libidinous character of self-preservative instincts Since venturing further step of recognizing sexual instinct as Eros, all-sustaining Deriving narcissistic libido of ego from sum of libido quantities bringing about mutual adherence of somatic cells
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Risk of Having Only Libidinous Instincts
positions.content: Now find ourselves suddenly confronted with question If self-preservative instincts also of libidinous kind, then perhaps we have no other instincts at all than libidinous ones At least no others apparent Then must admit critics right who suspected psychoanalysis makes sexuality explanation of everything
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Result Not Intended
positions.content: This result at all events one not intended by us On contrary, took as starting point sharp distinction between ego-instincts (=death-instincts) and sexual instincts (=life-instincts) Were prepared to reckon even alleged self-preservative instincts among death-instincts (position since corrected/withdrawn)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Dualistic Standpoint Maintained
positions.content: Our standpoint was dualistic from beginning, and is so today more sharply than before Since we no longer call contrasting tendencies egoistic and sexual instincts But life-instincts and death-instincts Jung's libido theory on other hand is monistic
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Jung's Monistic Confusion
positions.content: Jung applied term libido to his only instinctive energy Was bound to create confusion but should have no further effect on us We suspect there are in ego other instincts than those of self-preservation Only we ought to be in position to demonstrate them
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Analysis of Ego Progress Insufficient
positions.content: Unfortunately so little progress made in analysis of ego That this proof becomes extraordinarily difficult of attainment Libidinous instincts of ego may indeed be conjoined in special way with other ego-instincts of which we yet know nothing
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Narcissism Conjecture Already Present
positions.content: Before ever we clearly recognized narcissism Conjecture was already present in psychoanalysts' minds that ego-instincts had drawn libidinous components to themselves But these merely vague possibilities which opponents will hardly take into account
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Analysis Only Demonstrates Libidinous Impulses
positions.content: Remains awkward fact that analysis up to now only put us in position of demonstrating libidinous impulses Conclusion that therefore there are no others is one to which we do not assent Present inability to demonstrate doesn't prove non-existence
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: New Polarity: Love (Tenderness) vs. Hate (Aggression)
positions.content: In obscurity shrouding instinct theory, shall not do well to reject idea promising light Have made antithesis between life and death-instincts our point of departure Object-love itself displays second polarity: that of love (tenderness) and hate (aggression)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sadism as Death-Instinct Component
positions.content: What if we could succeed in relating these two polarities to each other? Have long recognized sadistic component of sexual instinct Can attain independence and as perversion dominate whole sexual trend In one pregenital organization appears as dominating part-instinct
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sadism Derived from Death-Instinct
positions.content: How derive sadistic impulse (aims at object injury) from life-sustaining Eros? Assumption suggests itself that this sadism properly death-instinct Driven apart from ego by influence of narcissistic libido So becomes manifest only in reference to object Then enters service of sexual function
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sadism's Progressive Role in Sexuality
positions.content: At oral stage of libido organization, amorous possession still one with annihilation of object Later sadistic impulse separates itself At stage of genital primacy takes over function of so far overpowering sex-object as sexual act carrying out demands Might even say sadism expelled from ego acted as guide to libidinous components of sexual instinct
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Hate-Love Ambivalence Setup
positions.content: Where original sadism experiences no abatement or fusion Well-known hate-love ambivalence of love-life is set up This provides example of death-instinct though displaced one
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Masochism as Return to Earlier Phase
positions.content: Conception not evident, creates mystical impression May appear we attempted at all costs to find way out of impasse But assumption is no new one; we made it once before when no question of impasse Clinical observations forced view that masochism (part-instinct complementary to sadism) is to be understood as recoil of sadism on ego itself
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Masochism May Be Primary
positions.content: Turning instinct from object to ego is essentially same as turning from ego to object (new idea in question) Masochism (turning instinct against self) would then be in reality return to earlier phase of this, regression Exposition then given of masochism needs correction: masochism may also be primary (what was there concerned to deny)
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Conjugation Effect as Prototype
positions.content: Return to life-sustaining sexual instincts Already learned from protozoa investigation that mingling of two individuals without consequent partition Just as copulation between two separating soon after, has strengthening/rejuvenating effect No sign of degeneration in descendants Seem to have gained capacity for withstanding longer time injurious results of own metabolism
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Blending Introduces New Stimulus Masses
positions.content: This one observation may be taken as prototype of sexual intercourse effect also But in what way does blending of two slightly different cells bring about life renewal? Experiment substituting for conjugation effect of chemical/even mechanical stimuli admits reply with certainty Comes about by introduction of new stimulus masses
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Union Increases Chemical Tensions
positions.content: This closely agrees with hypothesis that life-process of individual leads from internal causes to equalizing of chemical tensions (i.e., to death) While union with individually different living substance increases these tensions So to speak introduces new vital differentia which then have to be again lived out
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Nirvana-Principle Recognition
positions.content: For this difference between two there must naturally be one or more optima Our recognition that ruling tendency of psychic life, perhaps nerve life altogether Is struggle for reduction, keeping at constant level, or removal of inner stimulus tension (Nirvana-principle, as Barbara Low terms it) Struggle comes to expression in pleasure-principle Indeed one of our strongest motives for believing in death-instincts existence
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sexual Instinct Lacks Repetition-Compulsion Character
positions.content: But course of argument still disturbed by uneasy feeling That just in case of sexual instinct unable to demonstrate repetition-compulsion character Which first put us on death-instincts track True that realm of embryonic developmental processes offers abundance of such repetition phenomena
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Germ Cells as Repetitions
positions.content: Two germ cells of sexual propagation and their life history themselves only repetitions of organic life beginning But essential feature in processes designed by sexual instinct is nevertheless mingling of two cells Only by this is immortality of living substance among higher life forms assured
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Must Enquire into Sexual Propagation Origin
positions.content: Must make enquiry into origin of sexual propagation and source of sexual instincts in general Task before which lay mind quails and even specialists have not yet been able to solve Let us make condensed selection from conflicting accounts of whatever can be brought into relation with our train of thought
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sex as Advantageous Amphimixis Utilization
positions.content: One view deprives propagation problem of mysterious attraction By representing it as part of growth phenomenon (multiplication by division, germination, budding) Arising of propagation by means of sexually differentiated germ cells might be conceived In accordance with sober Darwinian mode of thought, as way of maintaining/utilizing for further development advantage of amphimixis
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Amphimixis from Fortuitous Conjugation
positions.content: Which resulted in first instance from fortuitous conjugation of two protozoa "Sex" would not thus be of very ancient origin Extraordinarily powerful instincts aiming at bringing about sexual union would thereby repeat something which once chanced to happen Since became established as being advantageous
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Same Question Recurs for Sex as for Death
positions.content: Same question now recurs as arose in respect of death Whether protozoa can be credited with anything beyond what they exhibit Whether may assume forces/processes becoming perceptible only in higher animals did first arise in more primitive For our purpose, view of sexuality mentioned above helps very little
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Objection: Presupposes Life-Instincts from Beginning
positions.content: Objection may be raised that it presupposes existence of life-instincts as already operative in simplest life forms For otherwise conjugation working against life expiration and making dying task harder Would not have been retained and elaborated, but would have been avoided If not to abandon death-instincts hypothesis, must associate them with life-instincts from beginning
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Working with Two Unknown Quantities
positions.content: But must admit we are working here at equation with two unknown quantities Anything else science can tell of sexuality origin amounts to so little That this problem may be likened to obscurity into which not even ray of hypothesis has penetrated
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Plato's Aristophanes Myth
positions.content: In quite another quarter encounter such hypothesis But of so fantastic kind—assuredly myth rather than scientific explanation—that I should not venture to bring it forward If it did not exactly fulfill one condition for fulfillment of which we are laboring That is to say, it derives instinct from necessity for reinstatement of earlier situation
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Plato's Three Original Sexes
positions.content: Refer to theory Plato in Symposium puts into Aristophanes' mouth Deals not only with origin of sexual instinct but also with most important variations in relation to object "Human nature was once quite other than now. Originally there were three sexes, three and not as today two" Besides male and female existed third sex having equal share in two first
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Zeus Divided Original Beings
positions.content: "In these beings everything was double: thus, they had four hands and four feet, two faces, two genital parts, and so on" Then Zeus allowed himself to be persuaded to cut these beings in two, as one divides pears to stew them "When all nature was divided in this way, to each human being came longing for his own other half" "And two halves embraced and entwined their bodies and desired to grow together again"
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Daring Assumption of Original Rent
positions.content: Are we to follow clue of poet-philosopher and make daring assumption That living substance at time of animation rent into small particles Which since that time strive for reunion by means of sexual instincts?
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Sexual Instincts Continue Chemical Affinity
positions.content: That these instincts—in which chemical affinity of inanimate matter is continued Passing through realm of protozoa gradually overcome all hindrances set to striving By environment charged with stimuli dangerous to life, impelled by it to form protecting covering layer
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Dispersed Fragments Achieve Multicellular Organization
positions.content: And that these dispersed fragments of living substance thus achieve multicellular organisation Finally transfer to germ cells in highly concentrated form the instinct for reunion I think this is point at which to break off
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Uncertainty About Personal Conviction
positions.content: Might be asked whether I am myself convinced of views here set forward, and if so how far My answer would be that I am neither convinced myself, nor am I seeking to arouse conviction in others More accurately: I do not know how far I believe in them Seems to me affective feature "conviction" need not come into consideration at all here
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Following Thought as Scientific Curiosity
positions.content: One may surely give oneself up to line of thought, and follow it up as far as it leads Simply out of scientific curiosity, or—if you prefer—as advocatus diaboli Without however making pact with devil about it
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Third Step Less Certain Than First Two
positions.content: Perfectly aware that third step in instinct theory which I am taking here cannot claim same certainty as two former ones Viz., extending conception of sexuality and establishing of narcissism These innovations were direct translations of observation into theory Subject to no greater sources of error than is inevitable in anything of kind
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Regressive Instinct Character Based on Observation
positions.content: Assertion of regressive character of instinct rests also on observed material Namely on facts of repetition-compulsion But perhaps I have over-estimated their significance At all events no way of working out this idea except by combining facts with pure imagination many times in succession
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Departing Far From Observation
positions.content: Thereby departing far from observation We know final result becomes more untrustworthy the oftener one does this in building theory But precise degree of uncertainty not ascertainable One may thereby have made brilliant discovery or gone ignominiously astray
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Distrust of Intuition
positions.content: In such work I trust little to so-called intuition What I have seen of it seems to me result of certain impartiality of intellect Only that people unfortunately seldom impartial where concerned with ultimate things, great problems of science and life
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Deep-Rooted Preferences Control Speculation
positions.content: My belief is that there everyone is under sway of preferences deeply rooted within Into hands of which he unwittingly plays as he pursues speculation Where there are such good grounds for distrust, only tepid feeling of indulgence possible toward results of own mental labors
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Self-Criticism Doesn't Require Tolerance
positions.content: But hasten to add such self-criticism does not render obligatory any special tolerance of divergent opinions One may inexorably reject theories contradicted by very first steps in observation analysis Yet at same time be aware that those one holds oneself have only tentative validity
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: No Disturbance from Surprising Processes
positions.content: Were we to appraise our speculations upon life and death-instincts Would disturb us but little that so many processes go on which are surprising and hard to picture Such as one instinct being expelled by others, or turning from ego to object, and so on
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Obliged to Use Metaphorical Language
positions.content: This comes only from our being obliged to operate with scientific terms i.e., with metaphorical expressions peculiar to psychology (or more correctly: psychology of deeper layers) Otherwise we should not be able to describe corresponding processes at all, nor even have remarked them
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Psychological Terms Are Metaphors
positions.content: Shortcomings of our description would probably disappear if for psychological terms we could substitute physiological or chemical ones These too only constitute metaphorical language, but one familiar to us for much longer time Perhaps also simpler
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Biology May Overthrow Hypothesis Structure
positions.content: Uncertainty of our speculation enhanced in high degree by necessity of borrowing from biological science Biology truly realm of limitless possibilities Have most surprising revelations to expect from it Cannot conjecture what answers it will offer in some decades to questions we have put to it
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Perhaps Overthrow Whole Structure
positions.content: Perhaps they may be such as to overthrow whole artificial structure of hypotheses If that is so, someone may ask why does one undertake such work and why should it be communicated to world? Well, I cannot deny that some of analogies, relations and connections therein traced appeared to me worthy of consideration
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Distinguish Function from Tendency
positions.content: Let us distinguish function and tendency more sharply than we have hitherto done Pleasure-principle is then tendency which subserves certain function Namely, that of rendering psychic apparatus as whole free from any excitation Or to keep amount of excitation constant or as low as possible
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Cannot Yet Decide Between Conceptions
positions.content: Cannot yet decide with certainty for either of these conceptions But note that function so defined would partake of most universal tendency of all living matter To return to peace of inorganic world
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Greatest Pleasure in Temporary Quenching
positions.content: We all know by experience that greatest pleasure possible for us to attain That of sexual act, is bound up with temporary quenching of greatly heightened excitation state Binding of instinct-excitation would be preparatory function directing excitation toward ultimate adjustment in pleasure of discharge
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Bound vs. Unbound Processes and Sensation
positions.content: Question arises whether sensations of pleasure and pain can emanate as well from bound as from unbound excitation processes Appears quite beyond doubt that unbound/primary processes give rise to much more intense sensations in both directions than bound/secondary processes
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Primary Processes Earlier in Time
positions.content: Primary processes also earlier in point of time At beginning of mental life there are no others May conclude that if pleasure-principle were not already in action in respect to them It would not establish itself in regard to later processes
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Search for Pleasure More Intense at Beginning
positions.content: Thus arrive at result which at bottom not simple one That search for pleasure manifests itself with far greater intensity at beginning of psychic life than later on But less unrestrictedly; it has to put up with repeated breaches
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Dominance More Assured at Maturity
positions.content: At maturer age dominance of pleasure-principle very much more assured Though this principle as little escapes limitations as all other instincts In any case, whatever it is in excitation process that engenders pleasure/pain sensations Must be equally in existence when secondary process at work as with primary process
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Further Studies Required on Tension
positions.content: This would seem place to institute further studies Our consciousness conveys from within not only sensations of pleasure and pain But also those of peculiar tension, which again may be either pleasurable or painful in itself
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Questions About Bound/Unbound and Tension
positions.content: Now is it bound and unbound energy processes we have to distinguish by help of these sensations? Or is sensation of tension to be related to absolute quantity, perhaps to level of charge While pleasure-pain series refers to changes in quantity of charge in unit of time?
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Life-Instincts Appear as Disturbers
positions.content: Must also be struck that life-instincts have much more to do with our inner perception Since they make appearance as disturbers of peace Continually bring along states of tension whose resolution experienced as pleasure
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Death-Instincts Function Unostentatiously
positions.content: While death-instincts on other hand seem to fulfill function unostentatiously Pleasure-principle seems directly to subserve death-instincts Keeps guard over external stimuli regarded as dangers by both kinds of instincts But in particular over inner increases in stimulation having for aim complication of task of living
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Innumerable Questions Without Answers
positions.content: At this point innumerable other questions arise to which no answer can yet be given Must be patient and wait for other means and opportunities for investigation Must hold ourselves too in readiness to abandon path we followed for time if it should seem to lead to no good result
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Only True Believers Expect Science as Creed Substitute
positions.content: Only such "true believers" as expect from science substitute for creed they relinquished Will take it amiss if investigator develops views further or even transforms them
positions.author: Freud

positions.position: Consolation in Slow Scientific Progress
positions.content: For rest we may find consolation in poet's words for slow rate of progress in scientific knowledge: "Whither we cannot fly, we must go limping" "The Scripture saith that limping is no sin"
positions.author: Freud
